title: Will a new Supreme Court Justice be confirmed before 30 April 2017?
preds:
Senate Confirms Neil Gorsuch as Supreme Court Justice
Republicans win bitter battle over President Trump’s pick to succeed late Justice Scalia on high court
https://www.wsj.com/articles/senate-expected-to-confirm-neil-gorsuch-as-supreme-court-justice-1491557404
Upping to 100 because I think this is done already.
Justice Gorsuch confirmed and on the way to his Supreme Court seat.👏🏻👏🏻👏🏻👏🏻👏🏻👍🏻

Gorsuch was confirmed, 54 to 45. Sens. Joe Manchin (D-W.Va.), Heidi Heitkamp (D-N.D.) and Joe Donnelly (D-Ind.) were the only Democrats who voted with Republicans to support President Donald Trump’s court pick. Sen. Johnny Isakson (R-Ga.) missed the vote. Gorsuch is expected to be sworn in next week at the White House.

Looks like the votes are lined up: http://www.foxnews.com/politics/2017/04/06/what-is-nuclear-option-how-mcconnell-plans-to-get-gorsuch-confirmed.html. Vote moving forward: http://www.cnn.com/2017/04/07/politics/gorsuch-confirmation-live/.
With the Senate rule change, and 55 senators indicating they'll vote for him, Gorsuch essentially has the confirmation wrapped up.

Scheduled for tomorrow, right after a bracing rendering of "Death March of the Damfool Democrats"  performed solely on Trumpets.  Owing to other recent events, medical care will still be available to treat the wounded feet in which the opposition have shot themselves.
The intent is to change the Senate rules for supreme confirmations and this will go thorough
The nuclear option having been exercised, I expect no further delay
Procedural change successful. Higher probability of confirmation. Looks likely to happen tomorrow.
Updating +2 points on news that McConnell used the nuclear option.
Procedural measures taken. Vote set for Friday PM. Will get more than enough votes to take his seat on the SC.
Reuters is announcing that the Senate will change its rule regarding filibuster of Supreme Court nominees, and Gorsuch will face a vote this week; also, Republicans apparently have 50+ votes.

WASHINGTON — Senate Republicans changed longstanding rules on Thursday to clear the way for the confirmation of Judge Neil M. Gorsuch to serve on the Supreme Court, bypassing a precedent-breaking Democratic filibuster by allowing the nomination to go forward on a simple majority vote.

Close enough vote to make things interesting. Apparently invoking the nuclear option won't be as simple as I assumed; three GOP senators enough to prevent it, and not all moderate GOP senators are high on Gorsuch, have liberal constituencies, Roe v Wade concerns, etc. From Wikipedia ("Nuclear option"): "In most proposed variations of the nuclear option, the presiding officer would rule that a simple majority vote is sufficient to end debate. If the ruling is challenged, a majority would be required to overturn it. If the ruling is upheld, it becomes a precedent. This would end what had effectively become a 60-vote requirement for confirmation of an executive or judicial nominee, or the passage of legislation." Good summary and link here: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/478098. Could get more interesting than I anticipated just one short day ago. Back to a Big E 88(%).

Dems apparently have enough votes to deny cloture, Reps plan to deploy nuclear option - only question is whether they can limit defections to no more than two on the rules change votes. 538 has a good rundown here [https://fivethirtyeight.com/features/the-democrats-found-the-votes-on-gorsuch-now-can-the-gop/] if the timetable gets pushed back from thu/fri, likelihood drops and things have a chance of dragging on past Apr.

It seems the Senate R's will end the filibuster, clearing the way for Gorsuch. He'll likely be confirmed even if the filibuster remains in place, but if an 11th hour deal is worked out that keeps the filibuster alive, it could provide a short delay on the Gorsuch confirmation. With Congress going on recess for the next two weeks, and then having to work on a FY17 CR or Approps, a delay confirming Gorsuch this week may cause his confirmation to occur in the beginning of May, and thus outside the time frame for the question.
Republicans appear resolved to get this confirmation done by invoking Harry Reid's "nuclear" option.
Politico seems to be taking it as a fait accompli.

At this point, given GOP's commitment to Gorsuch and Senate GOP's desire to confirm by end of this week (and invoke nuke option if needed), only visible risk that could derail is Russia-related bombshell. Putting lower risk on that happening this week, although Rep. Chaffetz told Morning Joe that "we may be doing something this week" about Flynn's payments from Russia and Turkey. Hard to incorporate a low probability, severe impact event, but Chaffetz clearly not pounding the table and also arguing against immunity, which would be likely to delay any potential bomb shells. Upping probability of confirmation this month to 94%.
R's talking nuclear option. Some D's signalling they may fold to protect the filibuster and 60-vote. Either way, Gorsuch likely to be approved by the end of the month.

Updating 2 points lower based on rising activism. The likeliest case is still that Republicans ram this through, despite Gorsuch being obviously unfit (really, workers should risk amputation rather than disobey corporate orders? :O)

Downgrading slightly. Still not sure if Republicans - as a whole - really want to impose nuclear option despite their rhetoric. I surmise the most likely course of action in the face of the filibuster would be for moderate Republicans + Democrats, out of concern for our nation's best interests, to pursue something similar to what the Gang of 14 did in 2005.
Moving on through the senate and the Republicans seem to be willing to pull out all the stops to see it go through

Just passed the Senate Judiciary committee. Expected for full vote by end of week.
Senate Republicans are already blaming Democrats for forcing them to change rules.
Pretty much a done deal, unless there is a surprise.
Bouncing around way too much. Up 15 until the Friday vote.

It needs to happen by the 10th. There seems to be resolve to get this through and block a filibuster including the nuclear option. Democrats are resisting strongly, possibly in reaction to the Republican refusal to vote on Merrick's Garland nomination. (Nominating Garland can be conceived as violating decades of precedent(politically convenient precendent)). If McConnell can block the filibuster attempt, Gorsuch will get confirmed.

The Democrats will have to take the risk of opposing any Trump nominee with minimal risk as he stays so unpopular. The candidate also tend to be from the far right which has been the his governing tendency up to this point.

Revisit this on April 10.  The push is on.  Republicans need a victory and it appears they are willing to pull out all the stops, including invoking the nuclear option, to make that happen.  Grassley and McConnell seem committed to making it happen.  The nomination will pass out of the committee today (April 3) and be up for a full Senate vote on Friday, April 7.  Grassley seems to think he's got 57 or 58 votes (http://thehill.com/blogs/floor-action/senate/326625-grassley-gorsuch-will-fall-short-of-60-votes), just two or three shy of the 60 needed to avoid the nuclear option.  However, if it doesn't happen on Friday, April 7, I don't think it happens before April 30.

Increasing estimate in response to McConnell's committment to do it this week (http://www.foxnews.com/politics/2017/04/02/mcconnell-vows-gorsuch-will-be-confirmed-this-week-schumer-predicts-wont-get-60-votes.html). McConnell knows he doesn't have a cloture-busting 60 votes, so he's basically signaling that he's going to invoke the nuclear option before any Democrat can take the floor for a filibuster. If he's decided to make that sacrifice, then I see no reason he can't get the nomination pushed through this week, well before the 4-30 deadline.

Top Senate Democrat says unlikely Trump court pick can clear procedural hurdle
http://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-trump-gorsuch-idUSKBN1740NH

McConnell essentially says it's gonna happen: htttp://www.slate.com/blogs/the_slatest/2017/04/02/mcconnell_says_neil_gorsuch_will_be_confirmed_to_supreme_court_this_week.html
Russia investigation would have to blow up in a huge way this week, before the Senate recess. 
Upping probability to near 90%, Mitch's evil snickering aside. Not quite 90% per gut...88 for Big E, that'll work. :)
Increasing seven points because this process is moving quickly.

I have updated this number based upon the statement of Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell stating that there will be a floor vote on or before 7 April 2017, and that he will use EVERY possible avenue of confirming Neil Gorsuch to the Court.
He might especially now that a couple  of Democrats have agreed to vote for the Republican nominee.

Despite the Dems catering to their presupposed base, Repubs have control and Gorsuch--who, BTW, happens to have a very good judical record and all the  Dems know this--wil be confirmed either 60+ or nuclear option.  The latter will trigger a snowball of non-lib nominees down the road.

Looking more and more like the Republicans will have to go with the Nuclear option: https://decisiondeskhq.com/vote-tracker/estimating-cloture-count-for-supreme-court-nominee-neil-gorsuch/. 
Bumping down to 95%, since I think they have a good shot of pulling off that nuclear option.

Just heard that debate starts next week and the confirmation vote is scheduled for April 7. Thinking about this, Senate GOP could view this as a get-Gorsuch-confirmed-and-then-we'll-look-seriously-at-Russia-and-Trump kind of deal, and Senate Dems might be OK (not happy, but OK) with that, given that he's essentially a straight-up trade for Scalia and they would love nothing more than the assurance of a serious investigation. Wildly speculative, but bumping up to 80% from 70%.

(Up 5) McConnell and Schumer are going toe to toe. This is becoming a power play, as much as it is about Gorsuch. Two possible outcomes: (i) cooler heads prevail and a compromise is reached, as in 2005; (ii) the two sides clash in a frontal assault, which the Republicans are in a better position to win. In both cases, Gorsuch will be approved, and there is enough time for this to happen by April 30, even if this requires some discussions during the recess. Now that McConnel has said Gorsuch would be approved by April 7, it will be a huge loss of face for him if approval does not come by April 30 at the latest. But not everything is in his hands, so I am leaving a chance for a delay.

Republicans will have to end a filibuster, and it seems difficult to for them to pull together a likely deal with Democrats to end the filibuster.

Trump said he's moving on to tax reform. I don't think he's setting up for a win there given tax reform is even harder than healthcare reform. The last overhaul was in 1986. At this point, it's a game of chicken and Dems are in a slightly better place at this moment in time compared to where they were prior to the demise of the Republican healthcare bill. Dems only power right now (since the deck is stacked across the board) comes from a renewed, activated Democratic base which opposes Gorsuch, acquiescence or caving in and the "business as usual" of insider politics . Schumer gets this I'm sure but Manchin and a few others will cave but I'm thinking they won't get to 8.

The Republicans will be keen to ensure that they have a victory for the President and the Democrats will be reluctant to be seen as too obstructionist on a losing ticket for their reputation. Barring any shocks, this should be one success in an otherwise shocking first 100 days for Trump.

I think I can follow how the rules of the confirmation system work, but maybe not the objectives. It seems the Democrats could hold up the process indefinitely, unless the rules are changed. The Republicans stopped Obama's candidate being confirmed for almost a year, do the Democrats want to stop Trump's candidate being confirmed until Trump leaves office? Surely the objective of the system is to get members of the Supreme Court who are acceptable to most people, not for each party to only confirm nominees that agree with their political views. From what is happening now it appears that there is no qualified person in the USA that has cross party support to simply make judgements based on the law. I find it difficult to believe that this was the intention of those who created the system. In theory the Supreme Court could just die out because of a lack of agreement on who to appoint. 
So my assumption is that at some point someone (probably Gorsuch) will be appointed, but maybe not until after 30th April.

Dems have delayed confirmation vote by a week: http://www.toledoblade.com/Politics/2017/03/27/Dems-force-1-week-delay-on-panel-vote-on-Supreme-Court-pick.html. While it still is likely Gorsuch will ultimately be confirmed, the filibuster puts the April 30 date in jeopardy, as Senate R's will have to muster 60 votes to end the filibuster, followed by another 60 to confirm Gorsuch.

Also in saying that the president is not above the law is a positive factor in gaining more credibility and reputation of impartiality which would help his nomination.

Neil Gorsuch has been nominated on 31 Jan. 2017. The question will be closed 89 days after his nomination. On average, the last 10 successful confirmations took 69.9 days (https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2016/02/13/us/how-long-does-it-take-to-confirm-a-supreme-court-nominee.html). Also, the Republicans have the power to confirm NG to the SCOTUS. They are trying to avoid filibuster, which takes time, but are willing to draw the 'nuclear' option I understand. With the "spread offense" being employed by Senate R's, it's unlikely the Gorsuch hearing will garner significant media attention compared to the Russia hearing and Trump's speech later that evening. Without it's own news cycle, Senators will probably not have strong constituent pressure to resist, especially those Senate D's in red states. If something egregious comes out during the confirmation hearings, this could have a significant impact. However, if the hearings are relatively benign and procedural, and Gorsuch satisfactorily answers questions about the Executive-Judicial relationship, there will be few reasons for Senate D's to block the confirmation beyond partisan politics and revenge over Garland.

(Up 10). Gorsuch's confirmation and the Republican health care bill will reach the Senate at about the same time, which would provide for some interesting dynamics. First, I believe McConnell will give priority to the vote on Gorsuch, as the health care bill would require a lot of time. Second, the Republicans are united in their support for Gorsuch, and some Democrats (Manchin (WV), Heitcamp (ND), King (ME)) have said they would not be against an up or down vote. Third, if a vote on Gorsuch is supported by 55-57 Senators, McConnell will find it easier to push for changing the filibuster rule for SC appointments. Fourth, all this should temper the Democrats' zeal to filibuster Gorsuch, as  this could (i) eliminate the filibuster rule and made a (much more contentious) second and even third Trump SC appointment an easy reality, and (ii) break their tenuous ties with moderate Republicans, which will be vital to defeat the health care bill.

Reiterating that I think this is going to happen. Repealing Obamacare is a priority for Republican senators, but getting another conservative on the supreme court is THE priority to keep the edge in the culture war for the next generation. Added to which there are some up-coming cases that make it urgent for them to get the conservative majority back on the court e.g. http://newsblaze.com/business/legal/florida-supreme-court-handed-us-supreme-court-second-amendment-case_75250/

Down 27 after coming up for a couple of weeks from sub-30. There is definitely a full agenda and it is more important that he get personnel approved by the Senate. If this does resolve as yes it will be by a whisker.
Major drop as I don't know how Repubs will be able to get this through on top of everything else. They've got to spend their energy whipping for AHA, which is a bigger battle.

This is a weird one. Over the last 50 years, it looks like around 90% of seats have been filled within 100 days of their vacancy (see http://www.pewresearch.org/fact-tank/2016/02/26/long-supreme-court-vacancies-used-to-be-more-common/), and around two-thirds have been filled in 100 days. If we treat the inauguration as a sort of "reset" button on filling the seat, we should expect it to be filled within 100 days with about 2/3 confidence.
That said, Supreme Court nominees are especially contentious (as we've recently learned), and the Democrats may engage in a Tit-for-Tat strategy of denying Trump's nominee purely in a punitive response to the Republicans' failure to advise and consent on Merrick Garland. I see this as slightly more plausible than not, meaning my estimation of the probability of filling the seat within the allotted 100 days should be lower than 2/3.
